title: 111_s2973
content: The "Small Business Job Creation Tax Act of 2010" may be cited as the Act. It introduces the Employer Payroll Increase Credit under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The "Small Business Job Creation Tax Act of 2010" introduces the Employer Payroll Increase Credit under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Each qualified employer is treated as having made a payment against the tax imposed for each qualified quarter equal to the credit amount, which is based on the applicable percentage of the qualified payroll increase. The applicable percentage is 20% for employers with fewer than 100 employees and 15% for employers with 100 or more employees. The total credit amount for any employer is capped at $500,000 for all qualified quarters. A qualified employer is defined as any American employer excluding the United States, any State, or any instrumentality thereof. A qualified payroll increase is the difference between a qualified employer's payroll for a quarter and the previous year's same quarter. Qualified payroll refers to all wages as defined by section. The qualified payroll increase is the amount of wages paid by a qualified employer to employees, limited by the contribution and benefit base. For railway labor, compensation is substituted for wages. Large employers have a special rule where no qualified payroll increase is considered. The Small Business Job Creation Tax Act of 2010 defines a "qualified quarter" as the calendar quarter including the enactment date and the following 3 quarters. Terms in this section have the same meaning as in section 3111. The term "employee" in this context only includes certain individuals. The term 'employee' in the Small Business Job Creation Tax Act of 2010 includes only citizens or lawful residents of the United States receiving wages from an employer for work within the US. The act exempts qualified employers from certain requirements if the total number of employees decreases from the previous quarter, excluding seasonal employees. Controlled groups of employers are treated as a single entity for tax purposes. The Small Business Job Creation Tax Act of 2010 treats controlled groups of employers as a single entity for tax purposes, with exceptions for non-American employers. New employers that come into existence after the enactment of the Act are eligible for certain benefits related to qualified quarters and payroll increases. New employers that come into existence after the enactment of the Act are eligible for benefits related to qualified quarters and payroll increases. The qualified payroll increase for a quarter is determined based on the employer's qualified payroll for that quarter and the preceding quarter. The Small Business Job Creation Tax Act of 2010 allows new employers to be treated as a single entity for tax purposes. The qualified payroll increase for a transition quarter is the difference between the employer's qualified payroll for that quarter and the preceding quarter. The Small Business Job Creation Tax Act of 2010 defines a transition quarter as a qualified quarter where the qualified payroll increase cannot be determined solely because the employer was not in existence during the preceding calendar year. A clerical amendment is made to the table of sections for subchapter B of chapter 65 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The Commissioner of Internal Revenue will notify employers about the new section 6433 of the Internal Revenue Code within 30 days of the Act's enactment. Additionally, the Commissioner will provide quarterly reports to Congress on enforcement actions against fraud related to this section. The new section 6433 of the Internal Revenue Code will include general statistics, cases of fraud, and updates on investigatory and prosecutorial actions. The amendments will be effective starting from the enactment of this Act.
